Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Differential Geometry and Statistics of Deformation Tensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Structural geology data and models rely on a variety of geometric concepts, such as directions in space, ellipsoids, and deformation tensors. In mathematics, these objects are often represented as elements of Lie groups and their associated symmetric spaces. This vast mathematical theory has been applied to geology in only a few instances. This project represents collaboration between two structural geologists and a mathematician; the goal is to develop three new applications of Lie groups to problems within structural geology. The first uses Lie group-based differential equations methods to compute non-steady deformations. This method is being applied to an existing dataset from a shear zone in New Caledonia. The second applies established statistics of ellipsoids to finite strain ellipsoid data from South Mountain, Maryland, which is a classic field location within the field of structural geology. The third develops a statistical theory of deformation tensors, and uses them to compute best-fit deformations and to quantify the uncertainty in data and models.

This project enriches the fundamental tool set that geologists use to describe data and make inferences from data. It opens the door to further cross-fertilization among geology, mathematics, and other fields using related techniques, such as medical imaging. The products of the project will be disseminated in scholarly publications, short courses, and free software distributed to the geology community. The project will facilitate collaboration and research between faculty from a four-year college and a research-intensive university. The study will contribute to undergraduate education at both institutions, and will provide funding for undergraduate research projects.

This project is supported by funds from the NSF EAR Tectonics Program and the Collaborations in Mathematical Geosciences Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Structural geology is the study of how rocks fold and fracture under the immense stresses present in the Earth. This basic scientific discipline can inform applications such as earthquake hazard assessment, dam construction, natural resource exploration, and carbon sequestration. 

Structural studies often involve painstaking field work and lab work, in which the geologist measures the spatial orientations and shapes of rock features. Because the resulting data sets are often small, imprecise, and irregularly sampled across the field area, they require rigorous statistical treatment. However, because the data are not simply numbers, but rather geometric information about orientation and shape, they require unusual statistical methods.

This project was a collaboration between two structural geologists (Basil Tikoff, UW-Madison and Sarah Titus, Carleton College) and a mathematician (Joshua Davis, Carleton College). We focused on developing new statistical techniques and adapting existing techniques from other fields (e.g., medical imaging, robotics, astronomy) to apply to structural geology field data.

Our computational and statistical tools are freely available at Davis' web site. These tools have been presented at meetings and in short courses, leading to some new domestic and international collaborations. In spring 2015, Davis led a seminar for graduate students at UW-Madison; each student applied the appropriate statistical tools to their thesis data. Carleton College undergraduates have also used tools developed in this grant for their thesis projects, including four mathematics majors with no previous exposure to the Earth Sciences.

Six publications have come out of this project (Davis and Titus, 2011; Davis et al., 2013; Scott et al., 2013; Davis and Giorgis, 2014; Michels et al., 2015; Davis and Titus, in review). The techniques were also used in two graduate theses from UW-Madison (Stetson-Lee, 2015; Michels, 2016) and four undergraduate theses from Carleton College: three in geology (Alexander, 2014; Radue, 2014; Wagner, 2014) and one four-student thesis in mathematics (Pedtke et al., 2014). We have presented portions of this work in 17 abstracts at domestic and international meetings since 2011.
